info.game_comments: Missing first 10 clues of the Jeopardy! Round.

(2, 1).clue: 21-year-old Lynda Kuerth swallowed 23 of these ballpark treats in 190 seconds without the buns

(3, 1).clue: The Union suffered its 1st defeat of this war at Charleston's Fort Sumter
(3, 1).correct response: the war between the Union and the Confederacy (the Civil War)

(5, 1).clue: In 1986, she took over Charlotte Rae's post taking care of the girls on "Facts of Life"

(2, 2).clue: John McPherson did this to 4444 women in just 8 hours, at the rate of 1 every 6.48 seconds

(3, 2).clue: The British suffered 1 of their 1st defeats of this war at Charleston's Fort Moultrie

(5, 2).clue: The I.M.F., it was led by Dan Briggs until Jim Phelps took over in the 2nd season

(2, 3).clue: In 1976, a 4-woman team did this to 12 chickens in 32.9 seconds

(3, 3).clue: The most damaging of these geologic disasters ever in eastern U.S. hit Charleston in 1886

(5, 3).clue: After "replacing" Lynn Redgrave on "House Calls", she replaced Meg Foster on Cagney & Lacey"

(2, 4).clue: The world's most common single-letter surname is this one, found in the 2nd word of this clue

(3, 4).clue: Though written in '35 & set in Charleston, this show, featuring the following, didn't play there until 1970:There's a boat dat's leavin' soon for New YorkCome wid meDat's where you belong...

(4, 4).clue: Number of zeros you need to write three hundred fifty thousand in numerals

(5, 4).clue: Between Barbara Bel Geddes & Barbara Bel Geddes, she played Miss Ellie

(6, 4).clue: "Relative"ly speaking, this 1970 song was a big hit for Tom Jones

(2, 5).clue: The only man ever to drive 48 of these in a single hitch was Dick Sparrow of Zearing, Iowa

(4, 5).clue: Type of angle that falls between obtuse & acute

(5, 5).clue: It was Meredith MacRae who replaced Gunilla Hutton as Billie Jo Bradley on this '60s series

(6, 5).clue: Theme song from the 1984 movie "Eddie & the Cruisers"

(1, 1).clue: Mahatma Gandhi's weight fell to 80 lbs. during a 3-week fast protesting ostracism of these "outcastes"

(3, 1).clue: He was the only president born on July 4th, though he probably kept silent about it

(4, 1).clue: The Encyclopedia of Sports calls it "A goal game, usually played in a swimming pool, w/7 men on a team"

(5, 1).clue: Some say Japan's transformation into a modern nation was based on producing this luxury fabric

(6, 1).clue: The only element on the periodic table that starts with "K", its symbol is Kr

(1, 2).clue: Time reported that children of Hameln, Germany proclaimed on his birthday in '33 "You are now our Pied Piper"

(3, 2).clue: Though his inauguration speech was the longest, his term was the shortest

(4, 2).clue: While subject of debate, most authorities place the origin of ice hockey in this country

(5, 2).clue: Apollo astronauts wore garments made of yarn coated with this DuPont non-stick substance

(1, 3).clue: On Dec. 5, when predominantly Mormon Utah became 36th state to consent, this came to an end

(3, 3).clue: President whose oath of office was administered by judge Sarah T. Hughes

(4, 3).clue: One who loves this sport is a "toxophilite", Greek for "bow loving"

(5, 3).clue: EA says this hat material was once made by wetting fibers with water or whey & beating them with sticks

(6, 3).clue: Temperature scale in which the freezing point of water is 0°

(1, 4).clue: Over 2 million New Yorkers turned out for election which chose him the city's 99th mayor

(3, 4).clue: "When they say 'Mr. President', I...turn around and expect to see Roosevelt", he said after his election

(4, 4).clue: In 1976, this bowl game was moved from Tulane Stadium to the Louisiana Superdome

(5, 4).clue: French for "caterpillar", it's associated with bathrobes & bedspreads

(6, 4).clue: Temperature scale in which the freezing point of water is 32°

(1, 5).clue: It was reported in June that Americans were hoarding $604 million worth of this, defying a 2-month-old law

(3, 5).clue: In 1874, 5 years after leaving office, he was elected to the Senate, becoming the only former pres. to do so

(4, 5).clue: The ITTF, the International Federation for this sport, holds a World Championship every 2 years

(5, 5).clue: The word "textile" comes from the Latin "texere", meaning to do this

(6, 5).clue: The opposite of the type of exercise featured at Fonda's, it means "in the absence of oxygen"

(0, 0).clue: The only 2 countries whose capitals end in "K", their names both end in "land"
